message_1:
Let X be a topological space and \textit{T} be a topology on X satisfying the separation axiom T4.

If A, B are two disjoint closed subsets of X, prove that there exists two disjoint open sets U and V containing A and B respectively.
message_2:
To prove this, we will use the fact that a topological space X with topology T satisfying the T4 separation axiom, also known as a normal space, has the property that for any two disjoint closed sets A and B in X, there exist disjoint open sets U and V containing A and B, respectively.

Since X is a normal space and A and B are disjoint closed sets, by the definition of normality, there exist open sets U and V in the topology T such that A ⊆ U, B ⊆ V, and U ∩ V = ∅.

Thus, we have found two disjoint open sets U and V containing A and B, respectively, as required.
